AnimationSystem.definition: This is the main attribute of the animation system insertion control. Controls the insertion of the fixture's animation system in the light output. Is used for animation effects where a disk is inserted into the light output.
AnimationSystem.explanation: Use this attribute to select or engage an animation wheel for fixtures that provide animation selection on one channel and animation rotation/indexing on another channel(s). The actual animator selection way - continuous or steps (when continuous, you can freely index the animation wheel) is defined via physical properties of channel sets of this attribute. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

AnimationSystemAudio.definition: Controls audio-controlled functionality of animation system (n) insertion.
AnimationSystemAudio.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)Audio as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n). In case that AnimationSystem(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)Audio as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemMacro.definition: Selects predefined effects in animation system (n).
AnimationSystemMacro.explanation: This attribute allows for selecting a fixture's predefined macro functions for the AnimationSystem(n)

AnimationSystemPos.definition: This is the main attribute of the animation system spinning control. Controls angle of indexed rotation of animation system (n) disk.
AnimationSystemPos.explanation: This attribute allows to set indexed position (angle) of a animation wheel and is typically used together with AnimationSystem(n) attribute which selects/engages the animation. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

AnimationSystemPosAudio.definition: Controls audio-controlled functionality of animation system (n) disk.
AnimationSystemPosAudio.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)PosAudio as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n)Pos. In case that AnimationSystem(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)PosAudio as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemPosRandom.definition: Controls random speed of animation system (n) disk.
AnimationSystemPosRandom.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)PosRandom as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n)Pos. In case that AnimationSystem(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)PosRandom as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemPosRotate.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of animation system (n) disk.
AnimationSystemPosRotate.explanation: This attribute allows to set speed and direction of continuous rotation of an animation wheel and is typically used together with AnimationSystem(n) attribute which selects/engages the animation. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this AnimationSystem(n)PosRotate as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n)Pos. In case that AnimationSystem(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)PosRotate as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemPosShake.definition: Controls frequency of the shake of animation system (n) disk.
AnimationSystemPosShake.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)PosShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n)Pos. In case that AnimationSystem(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)PosShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemRamp.definition: Sets frequency of animation system (n) insertion ramp.
AnimationSystemRamp.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)Ramp as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n). In case that AnimationSystem(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)Ramp as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemRandom.definition: Controls frequency of animation system (n) random insertion.
AnimationSystemRandom.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)Random as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n). In case that AnimationSystem(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)Random as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationSystemReset.definition: Resets the fixture's animation system features.
AnimationSystemReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's animation wheels or elements.

AnimationSystemShake.definition: Sets frequency of animation system (n) insertion shake.
AnimationSystemShake.explanation: When using this AnimationSystem(n)Shake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationSystem(n). In case that AnimationSystem(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationSystem(n)Shake as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheel.definition: This is the main attribute of the animation wheel's (n) wheel control. Selects slots in the animation wheel. A different channel function sets the angle of the indexed position in the selected slot or the angular speed of its continuous rotation. Is used for animation effects with multiple slots. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.
AnimationWheel.explanation: Use this attribute to select one of the possible animators on an animation wheel for fixtures that provide animation selection on one channel and animation rotation/indexing on another channel(s). The actual animator selection way - continuous or steps (when continuous, you can freely index the animation wheel) is defined via physical properties of channel sets of this attribute. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

AnimationWheelAudio.definition: Controls audio-controlled functionality of animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelAudio.explanation: This attribute controls how the animation wheel will behave when responding to an audio source for use with the AnimationWheel(n). When using this AnimationWheel(n)Audio as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)Audio as the Logical Channel attribute.
AnimationWheelAudio.visual: This attribute controls how the animation wheel will behave when responding to an audio source for use with the AnimationWheel(n).

AnimationWheelMacro.definition: Selects predefined effects in animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelMacro.explanation: This attribute allows for selecting a fixture's predefined macro functions for the AnimationWheel(n). When using this AnimationWheel(n)Macro as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)Macro as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelMode.definition: Changes control between selecting, indexing, and rotating the slots of animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelMode.explanation: This attribute describes selecting, indexing, and rotating of slots in an animation wheel (n).

AnimationWheelPos.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of slots in animation wheel. This is the main attribute of animation wheel (n) wheel slot control.
AnimationWheelPos.explanation: This attribute allows to set indexed position (angle) of a animation wheel and is typically used together with AnimationWheel(n) attribute which selects the animation. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

AnimationWheelPosRotate.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of slots in animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelPosRotate.explanation: This attribute allows to set speed and direction of continuous rotation of an animation wheel and is typically used together with AnimationWheel(n) attribute which selects the animation. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this AnimationWheel(n)PosRotate as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n)Pos. In case that AnimationWheel(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)PosRotate as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelPosShake.definition: Controls frequency of the shake of slots in animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelPosShake.explanation: This attribute allows to set frequency of shaking of an animation wheel and is typically used together with AnimationWheel(n) attribute which selects the animation. If there is more than one animation wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this AnimationWheel(n)PosShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n)Pos. In case that AnimationWheel(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)PosShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelRandom.definition: Controls frequency of animation wheel (n) random slot selection.
AnimationWheelRandom.explanation: Use this attribute to describe random effects of the Animation wheel prepared by the manufacturer of the fixture. When using this AnimationWheel(n)Random as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)Random as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelSelectEffects.definition: Selects slots which run effects in animation wheel (n).
AnimationWheelSelectEffects.explanation: Use this attribute to describe some effects of the AnimationWheel(n) prepared by the manufacturer of the fixture. When using this AnimationWheel(n)SelectEffects as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)SelectEffects as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelSelectShake.definition: Selects slots which shake in animation wheel and controls the frequency of the slots shake within the same channel function.
AnimationWheelSelectShake.explanation: When selecting a shake of an animation wheel slot and defining the frequency of the shake withing the same channel function, choose this attribute to describe the behavior. When using this AnimationWheel(n)SelectShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)SelectShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelSelectSpin.definition: Selects slots whose rotation is continuous in animation wheel and controls the angular speed of the slot spin within the same channel function
AnimationWheelSelectSpin.explanation: When selecting a rotation of an animation wheel slot and defining the angular speed of the rotation  withing the same channel function, choose this attribute to describe the behavior. When using this AnimationWheel(n)SelectSpin as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to AnimationWheel(n). In case that AnimationWheel(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the AnimationWheel(n)SelectSpin as the Logical Channel attribute.

AnimationWheelShortcutMode.definition: Defines whether the animation wheel takes the shortest distance between two positions.
AnimationWheelShortcutMode.explanation: This attribute describes whether the animation wheel takes the shortest distance between two positions.

BeamEffectIndexRotateMode.definition: Changes mode to control either index or rotation of the beam effects.
BeamEffectIndexRotateMode.explanation: Use this to describe a function that allows to change the mode of operation of beam effects.

BeamReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's beam lenses or elements.

BeamShaper.explanation: Use this attribute to describe beam shaper function of the device.

BeamShaperMacro.definition: Predefined presets for fixture's beam shaper positions.
BeamShaperMacro.explanation: Use this attribute to describe predefined macros of the beam shaper function of the device.

BeamShaperPos.explanation: Use this attribute to describe indexing of the beam shaper function of the device.

BeamShaperPosRotate.definition: Continuous rotation of fixture's beam shaper.
BeamShaperPosRotate.explanation: Use this attribute to describe spinning/rotation of the beam shaper function of the device.

BlackoutMode.definition: Close the light output under certain conditions (movement correction, gobo movement, etc.).
BlackoutMode.explanation: If the device provides a way to disable light output when gobo, color or other elements are moving or when for example movement position is being restored after external manual intervention, use this attribute to describe this behavior/settings.

BladeA.definition: 1 of 2 shutters that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
BladeA.explanation: Use this attribute to describe framing shutters or barndoors of the device. When only the Blade(n)A is used, it is controlling insertion of the complete framing shutter by moving the long edge. Eventual rotation of this edge is controlled by Blade(n)Rot attribute. If both Blade(n)A and Blade(n)B are used, the Blade(n)A is controlling one corner and the Blade(n)B is controlling the second corner of the framing shutter, thus together these attributes are controlling the insertion and rotation at the same time. Use the (n) enumerator to set correct blade - when looking at the projection, 1 is bottom (from positive to negative values in Y axis), 2 is left (from negative to positive values on the X axis), 3 is top (from negative to positive values on the Y axis) and 4 is right (from positive to negative values on the X axis). (When looking into the device lens, 1 is top, 2 is left, 3 is bottom, 4 is right). The physical values describe the amount of insertion, where at 0 the blade is completely out of the beam and at 1 the blade is fully covering the diameter of the beam.

BladeB.definition: 2 of 2 shutters that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
BladeB.explanation: Use this attribute to describe framing shutters or barndoors of the device in which the framing shutter is controlled by adjusting it's corners. This Blade(n)B is used in conjunction with the Blade(n)A attribute, where the Blade(n)A is controlling one corner and the Blade(n)B is controlling the second corner of the framing shutter, thus together these attributes are controlling the insertion and rotation at the same time. Use the (n) enumerator to set correct blade - when looking at the projection, 1 is bottom (from positive to negative values in Y axis), 2 is left (from negative to positive values on the X axis), 3 is top (from negative to positive values on the Y axis) and 4 is right (from positive to negative values on the X axis). (When looking into the device lens, 1 is top, 2 is left, 3 is bottom, 4 is right). The physical values describe the amount of insertion, where at 0 the blade is completely out of the beam and at 1 the blade is fully covering the diameter of the beam.

BladeRot.explanation: Use this attribute to describe rotation of the blades of framing shutters or barndoors. Use the (n) enumerator to set correct blade, when looking at the projection, 1 is bottom, 2 is left, 3 is top and 4 is right. (When looking into the device lens, 1 is top, 2 is left, 3 is bottom, 4 is right).

BladeSoftA.definition: 1 of 2 soft edge blades that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
BladeSoftA.explanation: Use this attribute to describe soft edge framing shutters or barndoors of the device. When only the Blade(n)A is used, it is controlling insertion of the complete framing shutter by moving the long edge. If both Blade(n)A and Blade(n)B are used, the Blade(n)A is controlling one corner and the Blade(n)B is controlling the second corner of the framing shutter. Use the (n) enumerator to set correct blade - when looking at the projection, 1 is bottom (from positive to negative values in Y axis), 2 is left (from negative to positive values on the X axis), 3 is top (from negative to positive values on the Y axis) and 4 is right (from positive to negative values on the X axis). (When looking into the device lens, 1 is top, 2 is left, 3 is bottom, 4 is right). The physical values describe the amount of insertion, where at 0 the blade is completely out of the beam and at 1 the blade is fully covering the diameter of the beam.

BladeSoftB.definition: 2 of 2 soft edge blades that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
BladeSoftB.explanation: Use this attribute to describe soft edge framing shutters or barndoors of the device in which the framing shutter in controlled by adjusting it's corners. This Blade(n)B is used in conjunction with the Blade(n)A attribute, where the Blade(n)A is controlling one corner and the Blade(n)B is controlling the second corner of the framing shutter. Use the (n) enumerator to set correct blade - when looking at the projection, 1 is bottom (from positive to negative values in Y axis), 2 is left (from negative to positive values on the X axis), 3 is top (from negative to positive values on the Y axis) and 4 is right (from positive to negative values on the X axis). (When looking into the device lens, 1 is top, 2 is left, 3 is bottom, 4 is right). The physical values describe the amount of insertion, where at 0 the blade is completely out of the beam and at 1 the blade is fully covering the diameter of the beam.

Blower.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a blower function.

CIE_Brightness.definition: Controls the fixture's CIE 1931 color attribute regarding the brightness (Y).
CIE_Brightness.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a feature that sets the brightness of chromaticity of CIE 1931 based color definition.

CIE_X.definition: Controls the fixture's CIE 1931 color attribute regarding the chromaticity x.
CIE_X.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a feature that sets the x parameter of chromaticity of CIE 1931 based color definition.

CIE_Y.definition: Controls the fixture's CIE 1931 color attribute regarding the chromaticity y.
CIE_Y.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a feature that sets the y parameter of chromaticity of CIE 1931 based color definition.

CRIMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that allows to choose a color mixing mode which is prioritizing higher Color Rendering Index.

CTB.definition: Controls the fixture's "Correct to blue" wheel or mixing system.
CTB.explanation: Choose this attribute to control a function that modifies the Color Temperature of a fixture's light output. CTB increases the Color Temperature from its default. Physical values describe the resulting Color Temperature.

CTBReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's CTB flags or elements.

CTC.definition: Controls the fixture's "Correct to color" wheel or mixing system.
CTC.explanation: Choose this attribute to control a function that modifies the Color Temperature of a fixture's light output. CTC either increases or decreases the Color Temperature from its default. Physical values describe the resulting Color Temperature.

CTCReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's CTC flags or elements.

CTO.definition: Controls the fixture's "Correct to orange" wheel or mixing system.
CTO.explanation: Choose this attribute to control a function that modifies the Color Temperature of a fixture's light output. CTO decreases the Color Temperature from its default. Physical values describe the resulting Color Temperature.

CTOReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's CTO flags or elements.

ChromaticMode.definition: Selects chromatic behavior of the device.
ChromaticMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that defines if CCT related channels (CTC, CTO, CTB...) influence only white colors or whether CCT is applied also to mixed colors.

Color.definition: The fixture’s color wheel (n). Selects colors in color wheel (n). This is the main attribute of color wheel’s (n) wheel control.
Color.explanation: Any device that can create colors by changing a mechanical color wheel inside the device uses this attribute to describe the different colors possible. If there is more than one color wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

ColorAdd_B.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's blue emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_B.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Blue color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_BC.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's light-blue emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_BC.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Light Blue color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_BM.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's purple emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_BM.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Purple (Deep Blue) color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_C.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's cyan emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_C.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Cyan color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_CW.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's cool white emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_CW.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Cool White color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_G.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's green emitters for direct additive color mixing
ColorAdd_G.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Green color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_GC.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's blue-green emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_GC.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Blue-Green color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_GY.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's lime emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_GY.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Lime color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_M.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's magenta emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_M.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Magenta color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_R.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's red emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_R.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Red color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_RM.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's pink emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_RM.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Pink color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_RY.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's amber emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_RY.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Amber color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_UV.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's UV emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_UV.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive UV color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_W.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's white emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_W.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive White color/emitter with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_WW.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's warm white emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_WW.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Warm White color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorAdd_Y.definition: Controls the intensity of the fixture's yellow emitters for direct additive color mixing.
ColorAdd_Y.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Yellow color/emitter/flag with direct access to the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorCalibrationMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a feature that enable or disable color calibrations of the device.

ColorConsistency.explanation: Some devices allow to eliminate inconsistencies of color mixing output due to intensity drop caused by thermal management. In devices that allow to enable/disable internal color consistency setting, use this attribute to describe a such function.

ColorControl.explanation: Use this to describe some color related control functions of the device.

ColorEffects.definition: Selects predefined color effects built into the fixture.
ColorEffects.explanation: Use this attribute to control selecting predefined color effects built into the fixture

ColorMacro.definition: Selects predefined colors that are programmed in the fixture's firmware.
ColorMacro.explanation: Choose this attribute to control the selection of predefined fixed colors, like Color Presets or Swatchbook Colors. The individual colors are defined by linking wheel slots to channel sets. If there is more than one color macro the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which color macro will be controlled.

ColorMacroRate.definition: Controls the time between Color Macro steps.
ColorMacroRate.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function which is setting the time or speed of the Color Macro steps.

ColorMixMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's ColorMix presets.
ColorMixMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement for color mixing elements.

ColorMixMode.definition: Changes control between selecting continuous selection, half selection, random selection, color spinning, etc. in color mixing.
ColorMixMode.explanation: For devices, that allow setting of mode of operation or relationship of elements of the color mixing system of the fixture, for example color wheel selection modes, or additive/subtractive/... relationship of color mixing systems within the fixture.

ColorMixReset.definition: Resets the fixture's color mixing system.
ColorMixReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's color mixing system.

ColorMode.definition: Changes control between selecting, continuous selection, half selection, random selection, color spinning, etc. in colors of color wheel (n).
ColorMode.explanation: This attribute describes between selecting, continuous selection, half selection, random selection, color spinning, etc. of colors in a color wheel (n).

ColorModelMode.explanation: In devices that have a function to allow switching between various ways of color mixing (CMY, RGB, HSV...), this attribute is used to describe this function.

ColorRGB_Blue.definition: Controls the fixture's blue attribute for indirect RGB color mixing.
ColorRGB_Blue.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Blue color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorRGB_Cyan.definition: Controls the fixture's cyan attribute for indirect CMY color mixing.
ColorRGB_Cyan.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Cyan color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorRGB_Green.definition: Controls the fixture's green attribute for indirect RGB color mixing.
ColorRGB_Green.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Green color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorRGB_Magenta.definition: Controls the fixture's magenta attribute for indirect CMY color mixing.
ColorRGB_Magenta.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Magenta color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorRGB_Quality.definition: Controls the fixture's quality attribute for indirect color mixing.
ColorRGB_Quality.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function of the device that allows the operator to control the quality parameter of the device's color mixing.

ColorRGB_Red.definition: Controls the fixture's red attribute for indirect RGB color mixing.
ColorRGB_Red.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive Red color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorRGB_Yellow.definition: Controls the fixture's yellow attribute for indirect CMY color mixing.
ColorRGB_Yellow.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or saturation of an additive yellow color/emitter/flag, where the device is making internal adjustments of the color and the operator thus has an indirect control of the color. physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output/saturation.

ColorSettingsReset.definition: Resets settings of color control channel.
ColorSettingsReset.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function which allows to set various color related settings back to the default state.

ColorSub_B.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's blue filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_B.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Blue color flag/filter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorSub_C.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's cyan filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_C.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Cyan color flag/filter/emitter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorSub_G.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's green filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_G.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Green color flag/filter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorSub_M.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's magenta filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_M.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Magenta color flag/filter/emitter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorSub_R.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's red filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_R.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Red color flag/filter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorSub_Y.definition: Controls the insertion of the fixture's yellow filter flag for direct subtractive color mixing.
ColorSub_Y.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of insertion or saturation of a subtractive Yellow color flag/filter/emitter with direct access to the color. The color is the resulting color when the filter is fully inserted. Physical values go from 0 = no insertion/no color, to 1 = full insertion/full color saturation.

ColorUniformity.explanation: In devices that allow to set a color uniformity between multiple fixtures use this attribute to describe a such function.

ColorWheelAudio.definition: Controls audio-controlled functionality of color wheel (n).
ColorWheelAudio.explanation: The device internal audio-based color wheel selection frequency will be controlled by this attribute. If there is more than one color wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Color(n)WheelAudio as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Color(n). In case that Color(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Color(n)WheelAudio as the Logical Channel attribute.

ColorWheelIndex.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of color wheel (n)
ColorWheelIndex.explanation: The color wheel index describes an agle of rotation of the color wheel to exactly reproduce any mixture/position of the color wheel itself. The wild card will identify which color wheel will be indexed. When using this Color(n)WheelIndex as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Color(n). In case that Color(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Color(n)WheelIndex as the Logical Channel attribute.

ColorWheelRandom.definition: Controls frequency of color wheel´s (n) random color slot selection.
ColorWheelRandom.explanation: The device internal random color wheel selection frequency will be controlled by this attribute. If there is more than one color wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Color(n)WheelRandom as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Color(n). In case that Color(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Color(n)WheelRandom as the Logical Channel attribute.

ColorWheelReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's color wheels.

ColorWheelSelectMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's color wheel.
ColorWheelSelectMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of color wheel(s).

ColorWheelShortcutMode.definition: Defines whether the color wheel takes the shortest distance between two colors.
ColorWheelShortcutMode.explanation: This attribute describes whether the color wheel takes the shortest distance between two colors.

ColorWheelSpin.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of color wheel (n).
ColorWheelSpin.explanation: For special effects of a continuous rotating color wheel this attribute controls the direction of ration and the speed of rotation. If there is more than one color wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Color(n)WheelSpin as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Color(n). In case that Color(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Color(n)WheelSpin as the Logical Channel attribute.

Control.definition: Controls the channel of a fixture.
Control.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function (typically a DMX channel) which provides access to settings and to controls allowing changes of the behavior of the device, like striking and dousing of the lamp and so on. These individual settings or for example lamp controls are then described by their specific attributes. If there is more than one control channel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which control channel will be controlled.

CustomColor.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that allows to save a custom color into the lighting device.

CyanMode.definition: Controls how Cyan is used within the fixture's cyan CMY-mixing feature.
CyanMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe the mode of operation of the Cyan.

DMXInput.explanation: Use this attribute to describe behavior that allows changing the source of the DMX signal.

DigitalZoom.definition: Controls the image size within the defined projection. Used on digital projection based devices
DigitalZoom.explanation: Use this to describe a zoom of for example a digital projector, where the image changes size but the beam angle remains the same.

Dimmer.definition: Controls the intensity of a fixture.
Dimmer.explanation: Gradual (fading) change of intensity or brightness or in some cases even opacity shall be controlled with this attribute. Physical values go from 0 = no output, to 1 = full output. If a software makes use of an overall intensity control such as a grandmaster, it is important for the application to understand which attribute to change. In that scenario the dimmer attribute shall be the main intensity, brightness or opacity change.

DimmerCurve.definition: Selects different dimmer curves of the fixture.
DimmerCurve.explanation: Switching between different types of dimming curves provided by the device is described with this attribute.

DimmerMode.explanation: Switching between different types of dimming modes is described with this attribute.

DimmerReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's dimmer, dimmer flags or other dimming elements.

DisplayIntensity.explanation: For fixtures with the possibility to adjust the brightness of their menu display screen, use this attribute to describe such functionality.

Dummy.explanation: Use this attribute for functions that do not define any functions. They might be for example reserved for later use.

Effects.definition: Generically predefined macros and effects of a fixture.
Effects.explanation: Use this attribute to describe some effects and macros that are not possible to describe with some specific attribute.

EffectsAdjust.explanation: Use this to set some parameter of some generic effect.

EffectsFade.definition: Snapping or smooth look of running effects.
EffectsFade.explanation: Use this attribute to set fade of some unspecified, generic effects.

EffectsPos.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of slot/effect in effect wheel/macro (n). This is the main attribute of effect wheel/macro (n) slot/effect control.
EffectsPos.explanation: Use this to set angle parameter of some generic effect.

EffectsPosRotate.definition: Controls speed and direction of slot/effect in effect wheel (n).
EffectsPosRotate.explanation: When using this Effects(n)PosRotate as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Effects(n)Pos. In case that Effects(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Effects(n)PosRotate as the Logical Channel attribute.

EffectsRate.explanation: Use this attribute to set frequency of some unspecified, generic effects.

EffectsSync.definition: Sets offset between running effects and effects 2.
EffectsSync.explanation: Use this attribute to describe offsets between some generic effects.

Fan.explanation: Use this to describe a function that controls a fan of a device.

FanMode.explanation: Use this attribute to switch between different types of fan control modes (for example auto, high, silent).

Fans.definition: Controls a fixture or device fan.
Fans.explanation: For devices that allow to set a fan speed, use this attribute to describe this function.

FieldOfView.explanation: Use this attribute to describe features controlling field of view of video projection.

FixtureCalibrationReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's calibrations.

FixtureGlobalReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger a complete internal reset of the fixture.

Focus.definition: Controls the sharpness of the fixture's spot light. Can blur or sharpen the edge of the spot.
Focus.explanation: Use this attribute to describe the sharpening/focusing function of the device. Some may call it the Edge.

FocusAdjust.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function which sets some parameters or behaviors that make the optical system of the device to automatically keep the projection focused.

FocusDistance.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function which sets a distance at which the optical system of the device will automatically keep the projection focused.

FocusMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's focus.
FocusMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of focus.

FocusMode.definition: Changes modes of the fixture’s focus - manual or auto- focus.
FocusMode.explanation: Use this to describe a function that allows to change the mode of the focus.

FocusReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's framing shutter or focus lenses or elements.

Fog.explanation: A function that controls fog/haze function of a fog machine.

FollowSpotMode.explanation: For fixtures that allow remote enabling/disabling various types of follow spot related features, use this attribute to describe the behavior.

FrameMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's shapers.
FrameMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of framing.

FrameReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's framing shutter or framing elements.

Frost.definition: The ability to soften the fixture's spot light with a frosted lens.
Frost.explanation: For devices that allow to control insertion of frost lens or flag into the beam, to soften it, use this attribute to describe this function.

FrostMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's frost (n).
FrostMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of frost. If there is more than one frost the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which frost will be controlled.

FrostPulseClose.definition: Sets frequency of frost's closing pulse.
FrostPulseClose.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function that allows to set to frost into a mode where the frost pulses with slower closing and faster opening behavior. When using this Frost(n)PulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Frost(n). In case that Frost(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Frost(n)PulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

FrostPulseOpen.definition: Sets frequency of frost's opening pulse
FrostPulseOpen.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function that allows to set to frost into a mode where the frost pulses with slower opening and faster closing behavior. When using this Frost(n)PulseOpen as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Frost(n). In case that Frost(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Frost(n)PulseOpen as the Logical Channel attribute.

FrostRamp.explanation: When using this Frost(n)Ramp as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Frost(n). In case that Frost(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Frost(n)Ramp as the Logical Channel attribute.

Function.definition: Generally controls features of the fixture.
Function.explanation: If you cannot find other attribute that would describe a feature of the Power/Control channel, use this generic attribute.

GlobalMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement which is used on elements of the device.

Gobo.definition: The fixture’s gobo wheel (n). This is the main attribute of gobo wheel’s (n) wheel control. Selects gobos in gobo wheel (n). A different channel function sets the angle of the indexed position in the selected gobo or the angular speed of its continuous rotation.
Gobo.explanation: Use this attribute to select gobo in a gobo wheel for fixtures that provide gobo selection on one channel and gobo rotation/indexing on another channel(s). The actual gobo selection way - continuous or steps (when continuous, you can freely index the gobo wheel) is defined via physical properties of channel sets of this attribute. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

GoboPos.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of gobos in gobo wheel (n). This is the main attribute of gobo wheel’s (n) wheel slot control.
GoboPos.explanation: This attribute allows to set indexed position (angle) of a gobo in a gobo wheel and is typically used together with Gobo(n) attribute which selects the gobo. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

GoboPosRotate.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of gobos in gobo wheel (n).
GoboPosRotate.explanation: This attribute allows to set speed and direction of continuous rotation of a gobo in a gobo wheel and is typically used together with Gobo(n) attribute which selects the gobo. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)PosRotate as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n)Pos. In case that Gobo(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)PosRotate as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboPosShake.definition: Controls frequency of the shake of gobos in gobo wheel (n).
GoboPosShake.explanation: This attribute allows to set frequency of shaking of a gobo in a gobo wheel and is typically used together with Gobo(n) attribute which selects the gobo. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)PosShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n)Pos. In case that Gobo(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)PosShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboSelectEffects.definition: Selects gobos which run effects in gobo wheel (n).
GoboSelectEffects.explanation: Use this attribute for manufacturer defined fixture specific effects on a gobo wheel. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)SelectEffects as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)SelectEffects as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboSelectShake.definition: Selects gobos which shake in gobo wheel (n) and controls the frequency of the gobo’s shake within the same channel function.
GoboSelectShake.explanation: Use this attribute to control selection and shake speed of gobos, with gobo shake effect in gobo wheel, within the same channel function When using this Gobo(n)SelectShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)SelectShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboSelectSpin.definition: Selects gobos whose rotation is continuous in gobo wheel (n) and controls the angular speed of the gobo’s spin within the same channel function. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.
GoboSelectSpin.explanation: Use this attribute to control selection and spin speed of gobos, with continuous rotation in gobo wheel, within the same channel function. When there is more than one gobo wheel a wild card (numerical identifier (n)) will be automatically added to indicate which wheel is being controlled. When using this Gobo(n)SelectSpin as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)SelectSpin as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboWheelAudio.definition: Controls audio-controlled functionality of gobo wheel (n).
GoboWheelAudio.explanation: Use this attribute to turn on audio based gobo functions, like random gobo selection in the beat of the music. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)WheelAudio as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)WheelAudio as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboWheelIndex.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of gobo wheel (n).
GoboWheelIndex.explanation: Use this attribute to define indexed rotation angle of the gobo wheel for the gobos on the wheel When using this Gobo(n)WheelIndex as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)WheelIndex as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboWheelMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of color wheel(s). If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

GoboWheelMode.definition: Changes control between selecting, indexing, and rotating the gobos of gobo wheel (n).
GoboWheelMode.explanation: This attribute describes selecting, indexing, and rotating of gobos in a gobo wheel (n).

GoboWheelRandom.definition: Controls speed of gobo wheel´s (n) random gobo slot selection.
GoboWheelRandom.explanation: Use this attribute to set the frequency of a random gobo selection. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)WheelRandom as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)WheelRandom as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboWheelReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's gobo wheels.

GoboWheelShake.definition: Controls frequency of the shake of gobo wheel (n).
GoboWheelShake.explanation: For gobo wheel that provides wheel shaking function, this attribute allows to set the frequency of the shake. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)WheelShake as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)WheelShake as the Logical Channel attribute.

GoboWheelShortcutMode.definition: Defines whether the gobo wheel takes the shortest distance between two positions.
GoboWheelShortcutMode.explanation: This attribute describes whether the gobo wheel takes the shortest distance between two positions.

GoboWheelSpin.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of gobo wheel (n).
GoboWheelSpin.explanation: Speed and direction of a continuous rotation of a gobo wheel ('gobo rainbow effect') is control with this attribute. If there is more than one gobo wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Gobo(n)WheelSpin as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Gobo(n). In case that Gobo(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Gobo(n)WheelSpin as the Logical Channel attribute.

HSB_Brightness.definition: Controls the fixture's color attribute regarding the brightness.
HSB_Brightness.explanation: Use this attribute to control a fixture's color Brightness

HSB_Hue.definition: Controls the fixture's color attribute regarding the hue.
HSB_Hue.explanation: Use this attribute to control the fixture's Hue (color)

HSB_Quality.definition: Controls the fixture's color attribute regarding the quality.
HSB_Quality.explanation: For devices that allow to adjust quality of HSB colors, use this attribute to describe this feature.

HSB_Saturation.definition: Controls the fixture's color attribute regarding the saturation.
HSB_Saturation.explanation: Use this attribute to control a fixture's color Saturation (richness)

Haze.explanation: A function that controls fog/haze function of a haze machine.

InputSource.definition: Defines media input source e.g. a camera input.
InputSource.explanation: This attribute allows to set a video input source.

IntensityMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's intensity.
IntensityMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of dimming behavior.

IntensityReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's intensity

Iris.definition: Controls the diameter of the fixture's beam.
Iris.explanation: An iris diaphragm made of movable leaves which allows to gradually change the diameter of the beam is described with this attribute.

IrisMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's iris.
IrisMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of iris(s).

IrisMode.definition: Changes modes of the fixture’s iris - linear, strobe, pulse.
IrisMode.explanation: Use this to describe a function that allows to change the mode of the iris.

IrisPulseClose.definition: Sets frequency of iris's closing pulse.
IrisPulseClose.explanation: A function that allows to adjust frequency of an iris based strobing where the iris pulses with slower closing and faster opening behavior. When using this IrisPulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisPulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

IrisPulseOpen.definition: Sets frequency of iris's opening pulse.
IrisPulseOpen.explanation: A function that allows to adjust frequency of an iris based strobing where the iris pulses with slower opening and faster closing behavior. When using this IrisPulseOpen as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisPulseOpen as the Logical Channel attribute.

IrisRandomPulseClose.definition: Sets frequency of iris's random closing pulse.
IrisRandomPulseClose.explanation: A function that allows to enable an iris based strobing in random intervals where the iris pulses with slower opening and faster closing behavior. When using this IrisRandomPulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisRandomPulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

IrisRandomPulseOpen.definition: Sets frequency of iris's random opening pulse.
IrisRandomPulseOpen.explanation: A function that allows to enable an iris based strobing in random intervals where the iris pulses with slower closing and faster opening behavior. When using this IrisRandomPulseOpen as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisRandomPulseOpen as the Logical Channel attribute.

IrisReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's iris.

IrisStrobe.definition: Sets frequency of the iris's strobe feature.
IrisStrobe.explanation: Strobing function created by fast movements of an iris is described with this attribute. When using this IrisStrobe as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisStrobe as the Logical Channel attribute.

IrisStrobeRandom.definition: Sets frequency of the iris's random movement.
IrisStrobeRandom.explanation: Strobing in random intervals created by fast movements of an iris is described with this attribute. When using this IrisStrobeRandom as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Iris. In case that Iris already exists in the same geometry, you can use the IrisStrobeRandom as the Logical Channel attribute.

KeyStoneA.definition: 1 of 2 corners that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
KeyStoneA.explanation: This attribute describes a behavior typically used on video projection, to adjust parallax correction.

KeyStoneB.definition: 2 of 2 corners that shape the top/right/bottom/left of the beam.
KeyStoneB.explanation: This attribute describes a behavior typically used on video projection, to adjust parallax correction.

LEDFrequency.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function which allows to change frequency of LEDs.

LEDZoneMode.explanation: For multipixel LED devices that allow to choose which zones of LEDs are being used, use this attribute to describe this function.

LampControl.definition: Controls the fixture's lamp on/lamp off feature.
LampControl.explanation: Use this attribute to describe functionality that allows to strike and douse the lamp of the fixture.

LampPowerMode.definition: Controls the energy consumption of the lamp.
LampPowerMode.explanation: For devices that allow to set different lamp modes (Low Power mode, Eco mode...), use this attribute to describe this function.

MagentaMode.definition: Controls how Magenta is used within the fixture's magenta CMY-mixing.
MagentaMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe the mode of operation of the Magenta.

MediaContent.explanation: This attribute selects content that usually is located in one of the folders selected. Any content selection process is possible with this attribute.

MediaFolder.definition: Selects folder that contains media content.
MediaFolder.explanation: This attribute selects one of multiple folders that (usually) contain media. Any folder selection process is possible with this attribute.

ModelContent.explanation: This attribute selects a 3D model that usually is located in one of the 3D folders selected. Any content selection process is possible with this attribute. If there is more than one content folder the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

ModelFolder.definition: Selects folder that contains 3D model content. For example 3D meshes for mapping.
ModelFolder.explanation: This attribute is selects specifically one of multiple folders for 3D content. Any folder selection process is possible with this attribute. If there is more than one folder the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

NoFeature.explanation: Use this attribute for functions that do not define any functions. They might be for example reserved for later use.

Pan.definition: Controls the fixture's sideward movement (horizontal axis).
Pan.explanation: PAN is one part of the movement that usually controls the horizontal movement. In regards to the fixture the Attribute of PAN will control the overall rotation around the basement of the fixture. If the fixture is mounted hanging it usually moves around the Z-axis. But PAN can also be used for virtual control of media server layers or other objects in virtual 3D environments. Usually PAN is used in relation with TILT.

PanMode.definition: Selects fixture's pan mode. Selects between a limited pan range (e.g. -270 to 270) or a continuous pan range.
PanMode.explanation: For devices that allow different modes of pan behavior, use this attribute to describe the behavior.

PanReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's pan.

PanRotate.definition: Controls the speed of the fixture's continuous pan movement (horizontal axis).
PanRotate.explanation: For fixtures with the ability to have a continuous pan rotation, the “Pan Rotate” control defines how fast (speed) a fixture can rotate about the pan axis. Usually, the horizontal axis.

PanTiltMode.definition: Selects fixture's pan/tilt mode. Selects between a limited pan/tilt range or a continuous pan/tilt range.
PanTiltMode.explanation: For devices that allow different modes of behavior of pan and tilt, use this attribute to describe the behavior.

PixelMode.explanation: For multipixel devices that allow to set behavior of pixel control (for example order of LEDs), use this attribute to describe such behavior/settings.

PlayBegin.definition: Defines starting point of media content playback.
PlayBegin.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that allows to set the starting time of media content playback.

PlayEnd.definition: Defines end point of media content playback.
PlayEnd.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that allows to set the end time of media content playback.

PlaySpeed.definition: Adjusts playback speed of media content.
PlaySpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to control the speed of media content playback

Playmode.explanation: For devices that allow to set a mode of media playback, for example play and loop, play and stop..., use  this attribute to describe this behavior.

PositionEffect.definition: Selects the predefined position effects that are built into the fixture.
PositionEffect.explanation: Effects which are built into the fixture, are based on movement and are of manufacturer specific nature so they cannot really be visualized are described with this attribute.

PositionEffectFade.definition: Snaps or smooth fades with timing in running predefined position effects.
PositionEffectFade.explanation: Use this attribute to describe functions that are adjusting fading or snapping behavior of some movement effects.

PositionEffectRate.definition: Controls the speed of the predefined position effects that are built into the fixture.
PositionEffectRate.explanation: Adjusting speed of some predefined movement effects is described with this attribute.

PositionMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's pan/tilt.
PositionMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement for pan/tilt.

PositionModes.explanation: For devices that allow different modes of behavior of their positioning system, use this attribute to describe the behavior.

PositionReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's positional system

Prism.definition: The fixture’s prism wheel (n). Selects prisms in prism wheel (n). A different channel function sets the angle of the indexed position in the selected prism or the angular speed of its continuous rotation. This is the main attribute of prism wheel’s (n) wheel control.
Prism.explanation: Use this attribute to select a prism in a prism wheel for fixtures that provide prism selection on one channel and prism rotation/indexing on another channel(s). If there is more than one prism wheel or carousel, the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

PrismMSpeed.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's prism wheel (n).
PrismMSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to set a speed of movement of prism(s). If there is more than one prism or prism wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which prism/wheel will be controlled.

PrismMacro.explanation: Use this attribute for manufacturer defined fixture specific effects on a prisms. If there is more than one prism wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Prism(n)Macro as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Prism(n). In case that Prism(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Prism(n)Macro as the Logical Channel attribute.

PrismPos.definition: Controls angle of indexed rotation of prisms in prism wheel (n). This is the main attribute of prism wheel’s 1 wheel slot control.
PrismPos.explanation: This attribute allows to set indexed position (angle) of a prism in a prism wheel and is typically used together with Prism(n) attribute which selects the prism. If there is more than one prism wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled.

PrismPosRotate.definition: Controls the speed and direction of continuous rotation of prisms in prism wheel (n).
PrismPosRotate.explanation: This attribute allows to set speed and direction of continuous rotation of a prism in a prism wheel and is typically used together with Prism(n) attribute which selects the prism. If there is more than one prism wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Prism(n)PosRotate as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Prism(n)Pos. In case that Prism(n)Pos already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Prism(n)PosRotate as the Logical Channel attribute.

PrismSelectSpin.definition: Selects prisms whose rotation is continuous in prism wheel (n) and controls the angular speed of the prism’s spin within the same channel function.
PrismSelectSpin.explanation: Selects prism whose rotation is continuous in prism wheel (n) and controls the angular speed of the prism’s spin within the same channel function. If there is more than one prism wheel the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which wheel will be controlled. When using this Prism(n)SelectSpin as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Prism(n). In case that Prism(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Prism(n)SelectSpin as the Logical Channel attribute.

ReflectorAdjust.definition: Movement speed of the fixture's frost.
ReflectorAdjust.explanation: Adjustment of the reflector of the device (for example setting it to a hot-spot output or a flat-field output) is described with this attribute.

Rot_X.explanation: Devices that can be rotated around the X-axis in space use this attribute. A typical usage is horizontal rotation of a video-layer in space (pitch axis).

Rot_Y.explanation: Devices that can be rotated around the Y-axis in space use this attribute. A typical usage is rolling of a video-layer in space (roll axis).

Rot_Z.explanation: Devices that can be rotated around the Z-axis in space use this attribute. A typical usage is vertical rotation of a video-layer in space (yaw axis).

Scale_X.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that scales the percentage of movement on an X axis.

Scale_XYZ.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that scales the percentage of movement on all X, Y and Z axes.

Scale_Y.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that scales the percentage of movement on an Y axis.

Scale_Z.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that scales the percentage of movement on an Z axis.

ShaperMacros.explanation: This attribute allows for selecting a fixture's predefined macro functions for the Blades/Shapers.

ShaperMacrosSpeed.definition: Speed of predefined effects on shapers.
ShaperMacrosSpeed.explanation: Use this attribute to control the speed of effects of shapers

ShaperRot.explanation: This attribute allows you to describe a function which rotates the complete carousel of framing shutters or barndors.

Shutter.definition: Controls the fixture´s mechanical or electronical shutter feature.
Shutter.explanation: Open/close style of change of intensity or brightness. Physical values go between 0 = closed, to 1 = open. If there is more than one shutter the wild-card (n) will be incremented and the number then indicates which shutter will be controlled.

ShutterReset.explanation: This attribute is describing a function that allows the operator to trigger an internal reset of the fixture's shutter flags or elements.

ShutterStrobe.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical strobe shutter feature.
ShutterStrobe.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)Strobe as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)Strobe as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobeEffect.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical shutter effect feature.
ShutterStrobeEffect.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobeEffect as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobeEffect as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobePulse.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical pulse shutter feature.
ShutterStrobePulse.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobePulse as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobePulse as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobePulseClose.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical closing pulse shutter feature. The pulse is described by a ramp function.
ShutterStrobePulseClose.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobePulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobePulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobePulseOpen.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical opening pulse shutter feature. The pulse is described by a ramp function.
ShutterStrobePulseOpen.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobePulseOpen as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobePulseOpen as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobeRandom.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical random strobe shutter feature.
ShutterStrobeRandom.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobeRandom as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobeRandom as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobeRandomPulse.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical random pulse shutter feature.
ShutterStrobeRandomPulse.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulse as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulse as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobeRandomPulseClose.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical random closing pulse shutter feature. The pulse is described by a ramp function.
ShutterStrobeRandomPulseClose.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

ShutterStrobeRandomPulseOpen.definition: Controls the frequency of the fixture´s mechanical or electronical random opening pulse shutter feature. The pulse is described by a ramp function.
ShutterStrobeRandomPulseOpen.explanation: When using this Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulseOpen as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to Shutter(n). In case that Shutter(n) already exists in the same geometry, you can use the Shutter(n)StrobeRandomPulseOpen as the Logical Channel attribute.

StrobeDuration.definition: Controls the length of a strobe flash.
StrobeDuration.explanation: Use this attribute to describe a function that can adjust the duration of an individual flash.

StrobeFrequency.definition: Controls the frequency of strobe flashes.
StrobeFrequency.explanation: Setting the frequency of strobing is described with this attribute.

StrobeMode.definition: Changes strobe style - strobe, pulse, random strobe, etc. - of the shutter attribute.
StrobeMode.explanation: Use this attribute to describe strobe, pulse, random strobe and other modes of the shutter attribute.

StrobeModeEffect.definition: Strobe mode random shutter effect feature. Use this attribute together with StrobeFrequency to define the type of the shutter / strobe.
StrobeModeEffect.explanation: When using this StrobeModeEffect as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to StrobeModeShutter. In case that StrobeModeShutter already exists in the same geometry, you can use the StrobeModeEffect as the Logical Channel attribute.

StrobeModePulse.definition: Strobe mode pulse. Use this attribute together with StrobeFrequency to define the type of the shutter / strobe.
StrobeModePulse.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function that allows to set to shutter/strobe into a Pulsing Strobe Mode. When using this StrobeModePulse as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to StrobeModeShutter. In case that StrobeModeShutter already exists in the same geometry, you can use the StrobeModePulse as the Logical Channel attribute.

StrobeModePulseClose.definition: Strobe mode closing pulse. Use this attribute together with StrobeFrequency to define the type of the shutter / strobe.
StrobeModePulseClose.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function that allows to set to shutter/strobe into a mode where the shutter pulses with slower closing and faster opening behavior. When using this StrobeModePulseClose as a Channel Function attribute, make sure that the attribute for the Logical Channel is set to StrobeModeShutter. In case that StrobeModeShutter already exists in the same geometry, you can use the StrobeModePulseClose as the Logical Channel attribute.

StrobeModePulseOpen.definition: Strobe mode opening pulse. Use this attribute together with StrobeFrequency to define the type of the shutter / strobe.
StrobeModePulseOpen.explanation: Use this attribute do describe a function that allows to set to shutter/strobe into a mode where the shutter pulses with slower opening and faster closing behavior.
